newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Brussels attracts Sony, Western Union.
newsitem.headline: Brussels attracts Sony, Western Union.

text.p: The Belgian capital's geographic location at the heart of western Europe, and its central role in European Union politics, together with a favourable tax regime, are earning it hundreds of new jobs.

Japanese electronics giant Sony Corp and U.S. electronic financial services group Western Union are close to setting up businesses in Brussels, spokesman Eric Van Coppenolle of the Brussels region's Economics Ministry said on Monday.

Money transfer and messaging group Western Union, part of the family of payment instrument businesses owned by First Data Corp of the U.S., will open a call centre for Europe, Middle-East and North Africa before the end of 1997.
The operation will employ 200 people. The total amount invested will be announced at a news conference by Brussels Economics Minister Jos Chabert on Wednesday, Van Coppenolle said.
The multilingual telephone centre, linked to the parent company in the United States, will be used to receive orders and take customers calls from all over the world.
Van Copenolle said Sony was interested in setting up a assembly and distribution unit in Brussels. Negotiations were still going on. An official decision was due in the next few months.
From Tokyo a Sony spokeswoman said the company could not confirm the plan.

Chabert's spokesman said, "The only thing I can confirm is talks are taking place for the opening of an assembly plant for mini-computers in or near Brussels. There is no date, we have not signed a thing yet." The plant would involve dozens of jobs.

Van Coppenolle said Western Union and Sony has chosen Brussels because of its role as Europe's capital, the availability of capable and multi-lingual staff and an attractive fiscal climate for foreign-owned operations.
